schemas.name: custom_attributes
schemas.description: A list of custom attributes to set on this resource.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter to put the cluster in.

schemas.name: dpm_automation_level
schemas.description: The automation level for host power operations in this cluster. Can be one of manual or automated.

schemas.name: dpm_enabled
schemas.description: Enable DPM support for DRS. This allows you to dynamically control the power of hosts depending on the needs of virtual machines in the cluster. Requires that DRS be enabled.

schemas.name: dpm_threshold
schemas.description: A value between 1 and 5 indicating the threshold of load within the cluster that influences host power operations. This affects both power on and power off operations - a lower setting will tolerate more of a surplus/deficit than a higher setting.

schemas.name: drs_advanced_options
schemas.description: Advanced configuration options for DRS and DPM.

schemas.name: drs_automation_level
schemas.description: The default automation level for all virtual machines in this cluster. Can be one of manual, partiallyAutomated, or fullyAutomated.

schemas.name: drs_enable_predictive_drs
schemas.description: When true, enables DRS to use data from vRealize Operations Manager to make proactive DRS recommendations.

schemas.name: drs_enable_vm_overrides
schemas.description: When true, allows individual VM overrides within this cluster to be set.

schemas.name: drs_enabled
schemas.description: Enable DRS for this cluster.

schemas.name: drs_migration_threshold
schemas.description: A value between 1 and 5 indicating the threshold of imbalance tolerated between hosts. A lower setting will tolerate more imbalance while a higher setting will tolerate less.

schemas.name: folder
schemas.description: The name of the folder to locate the cluster in.

schemas.name: force_evacuate_on_destroy
schemas.description: Force removal of all hosts in the cluster during destroy and make them standalone hosts. Use of this flag mainly exists for testing and is not recommended in normal use.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_failover_host_system_ids
schemas.description: When ha_admission_control_policy is failoverHosts, this defines the managed object IDs of hosts to use as dedicated failover hosts. These hosts are kept as available as possible - admission control will block access to the host, and DRS will ignore the host when making recommendations.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_host_failure_tolerance
schemas.description: The maximum number of failed hosts that admission control tolerates when making decisions on whether to permit virtual machine operations. The maximum is one less than the number of hosts in the cluster.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_performance_tolerance
schemas.description: The percentage of resource reduction that a cluster of VMs can tolerate in case of a failover. A value of 0 produces warnings only, whereas a value of 100 disables the setting.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_policy
schemas.description: The type of admission control policy to use with vSphere HA, which controls whether or not specific VM operations are permitted in the cluster in order to protect the reliability of the cluster. Can be one of resourcePercentage, slotPolicy, failoverHosts, or disabled. Note that disabling admission control is not recommended and can lead to service issues.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_resource_percentage_auto_compute
schemas.description: When ha_admission_control_policy is resourcePercentage, automatically determine available resource percentages by subtracting the average number of host resources represented by the ha_admission_control_host_failure_tolerance setting from the total amount of resources in the cluster. Disable to supply user-defined values.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_resource_percentage_cpu
schemas.description: When ha_admission_control_policy is resourcePercentage, this controls the user-defined percentage of CPU resources in the cluster to reserve for failover.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_resource_percentage_memory
schemas.description: When ha_admission_control_policy is resourcePercentage, this controls the user-defined percentage of memory resources in the cluster to reserve for failover.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_slot_policy_explicit_cpu
schemas.description: When ha_admission_control_policy is slotPolicy, this controls the user-defined CPU slot size, in MHz.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_slot_policy_explicit_memory
schemas.description: When ha_admission_control_policy is slotPolicy, this controls the user-defined memory slot size, in MB.

schemas.name: ha_admission_control_slot_policy_use_explicit_size
schemas.description: When ha_admission_control_policy is slotPolicy, this setting controls whether or not you wish to supply explicit values to CPU and memory slot sizes. The default is to gather a automatic average based on all powered-on virtual machines currently in the cluster.

schemas.name: ha_advanced_options
schemas.description: Advanced configuration options for vSphere HA.

schemas.name: ha_datastore_apd_recovery_action
schemas.description: When ha_vm_component_protection is enabled, controls the action to take on virtual machines if an APD status on an affected datastore clears in the middle of an APD event. Can be one of none or reset.

schemas.name: ha_datastore_apd_response
schemas.description: When ha_vm_component_protection is enabled, controls the action to take on virtual machines when the cluster has detected loss to all paths to a relevant datastore. Can be one of disabled, warning, restartConservative, or restartAggressive.

schemas.name: ha_datastore_apd_response_delay
schemas.description: When ha_vm_component_protection is enabled, controls the delay in minutes to wait after an APD timeout event to execute the response action defined in ha_datastore_apd_response.

schemas.name: ha_datastore_pdl_response
schemas.description: When ha_vm_component_protection is enabled, controls the action to take on virtual machines when the cluster has detected a permanent device loss to a relevant datastore. Can be one of disabled, warning, or restartAggressive.

schemas.name: ha_enabled
schemas.description: Enable vSphere HA for this cluster.

schemas.name: ha_heartbeat_datastore_ids
schemas.description: The list of managed object IDs for preferred datastores to use for HA heartbeating. This setting is only useful when ha_heartbeat_datastore_policy is set to either userSelectedDs or allFeasibleDsWithUserPreference.

schemas.name: ha_heartbeat_datastore_policy
schemas.description: The selection policy for HA heartbeat datastores. Can be one of allFeasibleDs, userSelectedDs, or allFeasibleDsWithUserPreference.

schemas.name: ha_host_isolation_response
schemas.description: The action to take on virtual machines when a host has detected that it has been isolated from the rest of the cluster. Can be one of none, powerOff, or shutdown.

schemas.name: ha_host_monitoring
schemas.description: Global setting that controls whether vSphere HA remediates VMs on host failure. Can be one of enabled or disabled.

schemas.name: ha_vm_component_protection
schemas.description: Controls vSphere VM component protection for virtual machines in this cluster. This allows vSphere HA to react to failures between hosts and specific virtual machine components, such as datastores. Can be one of enabled or disabled.

schemas.name: ha_vm_dependency_restart_condition
schemas.description: The condition used to determine whether or not VMs in a certain restart priority class are online, allowing HA to move on to restarting VMs on the next priority. Can be one of none, poweredOn, guestHbStatusGreen, or appHbStatusGreen.

schemas.name: ha_vm_failure_interval
schemas.description: If a heartbeat from a virtual machine is not received within this configured interval, the virtual machine is marked as failed. The value is in seconds.

schemas.name: ha_vm_maximum_failure_window
schemas.description: The length of the reset window in which ha_vm_maximum_resets can operate. When this window expires, no more resets are attempted regardless of the setting configured in ha_vm_maximum_resets. -1 means no window, meaning an unlimited reset time is allotted.

schemas.name: ha_vm_maximum_resets
schemas.description: The maximum number of resets that HA will perform to a virtual machine when responding to a failure event.

schemas.name: ha_vm_minimum_uptime
schemas.description: The time, in seconds, that HA waits after powering on a virtual machine before monitoring for heartbeats.

schemas.name: ha_vm_monitoring
schemas.description: The type of virtual machine monitoring to use when HA is enabled in the cluster. Can be one of vmMonitoringDisabled, vmMonitoringOnly, or vmAndAppMonitoring.

schemas.name: ha_vm_restart_additional_delay
schemas.description: Additional delay in seconds after ready condition is met. A VM is considered ready at this point.

schemas.name: ha_vm_restart_priority
schemas.description: The default restart priority for affected VMs when vSphere detects a host failure. Can be one of lowest, low, medium, high, or highest.

schemas.name: ha_vm_restart_timeout
schemas.description: The maximum time, in seconds, that vSphere HA will wait for virtual machines in one priority to be ready before proceeding with the next priority.

schemas.name: host_cluster_exit_timeout
schemas.description: The timeout for each host maintenance mode operation when removing hosts from a cluster.

schemas.name: host_system_ids
schemas.description: The managed object IDs of the hosts to put in the cluster.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: Name for the new cluster.

schemas.name: proactive_ha_automation_level
schemas.description: The DRS behavior for proactive HA recommendations. Can be one of Automated or Manual.

schemas.name: proactive_ha_enabled
schemas.description: Enables proactive HA, allowing for vSphere to get HA data from external providers and use DRS to perform remediation.

schemas.name: proactive_ha_moderate_remediation
schemas.description: The configured remediation for moderately degraded hosts. Can be one of MaintenanceMode or QuarantineMode. Note that this cannot be set to MaintenanceMode when proactive_ha_severe_remediation is set to QuarantineMode.

schemas.name: proactive_ha_provider_ids
schemas.description: The list of IDs for health update providers configured for this cluster.

schemas.name: proactive_ha_severe_remediation
schemas.description: The configured remediation for severely degraded hosts. Can be one of MaintenanceMode or QuarantineMode. Note that this cannot be set to QuarantineMode when proactive_ha_moderate_remediation is set to MaintenanceMode.

schemas.name: sdrs_advanced_options
schemas.description: Advanced configuration options for storage DRS.

schemas.name: sdrs_automation_level
schemas.description: The default automation level for all virtual machines in this storage cluster.

schemas.name: sdrs_default_intra_vm_affinity
schemas.description: When true, storage DRS keeps VMDKs for individual VMs on the same datastore by default.

schemas.name: sdrs_enabled
schemas.description: Enable storage DRS for this datastore cluster.

schemas.name: sdrs_free_space_threshold
schemas.description: The threshold, in GB, that storage DRS uses to make decisions to migrate VMs out of a datastore.

schemas.name: sdrs_free_space_threshold_mode
schemas.description: The free space threshold to use. When set to utilization, drs_space_utilization_threshold is used, and when set to freeSpace, drs_free_space_threshold is used.

schemas.name: sdrs_free_space_utilization_difference
schemas.description: The threshold, in percent, of difference between space utilization in datastores before storage DRS makes decisions to balance the space.

schemas.name: sdrs_io_balance_automation_level
schemas.description: Overrides the default automation settings when correcting I/O load imbalances.

schemas.name: sdrs_io_latency_threshold
schemas.description: The I/O latency threshold, in milliseconds, that storage DRS uses to make recommendations to move disks from this datastore.

schemas.name: sdrs_io_load_balance_enabled
schemas.description: Enable I/O load balancing for this datastore cluster.

schemas.name: sdrs_io_load_imbalance_threshold
schemas.description: The difference between load in datastores in the cluster before storage DRS makes recommendations to balance the load.

schemas.name: sdrs_io_reservable_iops_threshold
schemas.description: The threshold of reservable IOPS of all virtual machines on the datastore before storage DRS makes recommendations to move VMs off of a datastore.

schemas.name: sdrs_io_reservable_percent_threshold
schemas.description: The threshold, in percent, of actual estimated performance of the datastore (in IOPS) that storage DRS uses to make recommendations to move VMs off of a datastore when the total reservable IOPS exceeds the threshold.

schemas.name: sdrs_io_reservable_threshold_mode
schemas.description: The reservable IOPS threshold to use, percent in the event of automatic, or manual threshold in the event of manual.

schemas.name: sdrs_load_balance_interval
schemas.description: The storage DRS poll interval, in minutes.

schemas.name: sdrs_policy_enforcement_automation_level
schemas.description: Overrides the default automation settings when correcting storage and VM policy violations.

schemas.name: sdrs_rule_enforcement_automation_level
schemas.description: Overrides the default automation settings when correcting affinity rule violations.

schemas.name: sdrs_space_balance_automation_level
schemas.description: Overrides the default automation settings when correcting disk space imbalances.

schemas.name: sdrs_space_utilization_threshold
schemas.description: The threshold, in percent of used space, that storage DRS uses to make decisions to migrate VMs out of a datastore.

schemas.name: sdrs_vm_evacuation_automation_level
schemas.description: Overrides the default automation settings when generating recommendations for datastore evacuation.

schemas.name: notify_switches

schemas.name: number_of_ports

schemas.name: port_config_reset_at_disconnect

schemas.name: port_private_secondary_vlan_id

schemas.name: security_policy_override_allowed

schemas.name: shaping_override_allowed

schemas.name: domain_admin_user
schemas.description: The user account of the domain administrator used to join this virtual machine to the domain.

schemas.name: full_name
schemas.description: The full name of the user of this virtual machine.

schemas.name: join_domain
schemas.description: The domain that the virtual machine should join.

schemas.name: organization_name
schemas.description: The organization name this virtual machine is being installed for.

schemas.name: product_key
schemas.description: The product key for this virtual machine.

schemas.name: run_once_command_list
schemas.description: A list of commands to run at first user logon, after guest customization.

schemas.name: time_zone
schemas.description: The new time zone for the virtual machine. This is a sysprep-dictated timezone code.

schemas.name: workgroup
schemas.description: The workgroup for this virtual machine if not joining a domain.

schemas.name: windows_sysprep_text
schemas.description: Use this option to specify a windows sysprep file directly.

schemas.name: linked_clone
schemas.description: Whether or not to create a linked clone when cloning. When this option is used, the source VM must have a single snapshot associated with it.

schemas.name: template_uuid
schemas.description: The UUID of the source virtual machine or template.

schemas.name: timeout
schemas.description: The timeout, in minutes, to wait for the virtual machine clone to complete.

schemas.name: cpu_hot_add_enabled
schemas.description: Allow CPUs to be added to this virtual machine while it is running.

schemas.name: cpu_hot_remove_enabled
schemas.description: Allow CPUs to be added to this virtual machine while it is running.

schemas.name: cpu_limit
schemas.description: The maximum amount of memory (in MB) or CPU (in MHz) that this virtual machine can consume, regardless of available resources.%!(EXTRA string=cpu)

schemas.name: cpu_performance_counters_enabled
schemas.description: Enable CPU performance counters on this virtual machine.

schemas.name: cpu_reservation
schemas.description: The amount of memory (in MB) or CPU (in MHz) that this virtual machine is guaranteed.%!(EXTRA string=cpu)

schemas.name: cpu_share_count
schemas.description: The amount of shares to allocate to cpu for a custom share level.

schemas.name: cpu_share_level
schemas.description: The allocation level for cpu resources. Can be one of high, low, normal, or custom.

schemas.name: custom_attributes
schemas.description: A list of custom attributes to set on this resource.

schemas.name: datastore_cluster_id
schemas.description: The ID of a datastore cluster to put the virtual machine in.

schemas.name: datastore_id
schemas.description: The ID of the virtual machine's datastore. The virtual machine configuration is placed here, along with any virtual disks that are created without datastores.

schemas.name: default_ip_address
schemas.description: The IP address selected by Terraform to be used for the provisioner.

schemas.name: disk
schemas.description: A specification for a virtual disk device on this virtual machine.

schemas.name: attach
schemas.description: If this is true, the disk is attached instead of created. Implies keep_on_remove.

schemas.name: datastore_id
schemas.description: The datastore ID for this virtual disk, if different than the virtual machine.

schemas.name: device_address
schemas.description: The internally-computed address of this device, such as scsi:0:1, denoting scsi bus #0 and device unit 1.

schemas.name: disk_mode
schemas.description: The mode of this this virtual disk for purposes of writes and snapshotting. Can be one of append, independent_nonpersistent, independent_persistent, nonpersistent, persistent, or undoable.

schemas.name: disk_sharing
schemas.description: The sharing mode of this virtual disk. Can be one of sharingMultiWriter or sharingNone.

schemas.name: eagerly_scrub
schemas.description: The virtual disk file zeroing policy when thin_provision is not true. The default is false, which lazily-zeros the disk, speeding up thick-provisioned disk creation time.

schemas.name: io_limit
schemas.description: The upper limit of IOPS that this disk can use.

schemas.name: io_reservation
schemas.description: The I/O guarantee that this disk has, in IOPS.

schemas.name: io_share_count
schemas.description: The share count for this disk when the share level is custom.

schemas.name: io_share_level
schemas.description: The share allocation level for this disk. Can be one of low, normal, high, or custom.

schemas.name: keep_on_remove
schemas.description: Set to true to keep the underlying VMDK file when removing this virtual disk from configuration.

schemas.name: key
schemas.description: The unique device ID for this device within its virtual machine.

schemas.name: label
schemas.description: A unique label for this disk.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The file name of the disk. This can be either a name or path relative to the root of the datastore. If simply a name, the disk is located with the virtual machine.
schemas.deprecated:
The name attribute for virtual disks will be removed in favor of "label" in
future releases. To transition existing disks, rename the "name" attribute to
"label". When doing so, ensure the value of the attribute stays the same.

Note that "label" does not control the name of a VMDK and does not need to bear
the name of one on new disks or virtual machines. For more information, see the
documentation for the label attribute at: 

https://www.terraform.io/docs/providers/vsphere/r/virtual_machine.html#label

schemas.name: path
schemas.description: The full path of the virtual disk. This can only be provided if attach is set to true, otherwise it is a read-only value.

schemas.name: size
schemas.description: The size of the disk, in GB.

schemas.name: thin_provisioned
schemas.description: If true, this disk is thin provisioned, with space for the file being allocated on an as-needed basis.

schemas.name: unit_number
schemas.description: The unique device number for this disk. This number determines where on the SCSI bus this device will be attached.

schemas.name: uuid
schemas.description: The UUID of the virtual disk.

schemas.name: write_through
schemas.description: If true, writes for this disk are sent directly to the filesystem immediately instead of being buffered.

schemas.name: efi_secure_boot_enabled
schemas.description: When the boot type set in firmware is efi, this enables EFI secure boot.

schemas.name: enable_disk_uuid
schemas.description: Expose the UUIDs of attached virtual disks to the virtual machine, allowing access to them in the guest.

schemas.name: enable_logging
schemas.description: Enable logging on this virtual machine.

schemas.name: ept_rvi_mode
schemas.description: The EPT/RVI (hardware memory virtualization) setting for this virtual machine. Can be one of automatic, on, or off.

schemas.name: extra_config
schemas.description: Extra configuration data for this virtual machine. Can be used to supply advanced parameters not normally in configuration, such as data for cloud-config (under the guestinfo namespace), or configuration data for OVF images.

schemas.name: firmware
schemas.description: The firmware interface to use on the virtual machine. Can be one of bios or EFI.

schemas.name: folder
schemas.description: The name of the folder to locate the virtual machine in.

schemas.name: force_power_off
schemas.description: Set to true to force power-off a virtual machine if a graceful guest shutdown failed for a necessary operation.

schemas.name: guest_id
schemas.description: The guest ID for the operating system.

schemas.name: guest_ip_addresses
schemas.description: The current list of IP addresses on this virtual machine.

schemas.name: host_system_id
schemas.description: The ID of an optional host system to pin the virtual machine to.

schemas.name: hv_mode
schemas.description: The (non-nested) hardware virtualization setting for this virtual machine. Can be one of hvAuto, hvOn, or hvOff.

schemas.name: imported
schemas.description: A flag internal to Terraform that indicates that this resource was either imported or came from a earlier major version of this resource. Reset after the first post-import or post-upgrade apply.

schemas.name: latency_sensitivity
schemas.description: Controls the scheduling delay of the virtual machine. Use a higher sensitivity for applications that require lower latency, such as VOIP, media player applications, or applications that require frequent access to mouse or keyboard devices. Can be one of low, normal, medium, or high.

schemas.name: memory
schemas.description: The size of the virtual machine's memory, in MB.

schemas.name: memory_hot_add_enabled
schemas.description: Allow memory to be added to this virtual machine while it is running.

schemas.name: memory_limit
schemas.description: The maximum amount of memory (in MB) or CPU (in MHz) that this virtual machine can consume, regardless of available resources.%!(EXTRA string=memory)

schemas.name: memory_reservation
schemas.description: The amount of memory (in MB) or CPU (in MHz) that this virtual machine is guaranteed.%!(EXTRA string=memory)

schemas.name: memory_share_count
schemas.description: The amount of shares to allocate to memory for a custom share level.

schemas.name: memory_share_level
schemas.description: The allocation level for memory resources. Can be one of high, low, normal, or custom.

schemas.name: migrate_wait_timeout
schemas.description: The amount of time, in minutes, to wait for a vMotion operation to complete before failing.

schemas.name: moid
schemas.description: The machine object ID from VMWare

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name of this virtual machine.

schemas.name: nested_hv_enabled
schemas.description: Enable nested hardware virtualization on this virtual machine, facilitating nested virtualization in the guest.

schemas.name: network_interface
schemas.description: A specification for a virtual NIC on this virtual machine.

schemas.name: adapter_type
schemas.description: The controller type. Can be one of e1000, e1000e, or vmxnet3.

schemas.name: bandwidth_limit
schemas.description: The upper bandwidth limit of this network interface, in Mbits/sec.

schemas.name: bandwidth_reservation
schemas.description: The bandwidth reservation of this network interface, in Mbits/sec.

schemas.name: bandwidth_share_count
schemas.description: The share count for this network interface when the share level is custom.

schemas.name: bandwidth_share_level
schemas.description: The bandwidth share allocation level for this interface. Can be one of low, normal, high, or custom.

schemas.name: device_address
schemas.description: The internally-computed address of this device, such as scsi:0:1, denoting scsi bus #0 and device unit 1.

schemas.name: key
schemas.description: The unique device ID for this device within its virtual machine.

schemas.name: mac_address
schemas.description: The MAC address of this network interface. Can only be manually set if use_static_mac is true.

schemas.name: network_id
schemas.description: The ID of the network to connect this network interface to.

schemas.name: use_static_mac
schemas.description: If true, the mac_address field is treated as a static MAC address and set accordingly.

schemas.name: num_cores_per_socket
schemas.description: The number of cores to distribute amongst the CPUs in this virtual machine. If specified, the value supplied to num_cpus must be evenly divisible by this value.

schemas.name: num_cpus
schemas.description: The number of virtual processors to assign to this virtual machine.

schemas.name: reboot_required
schemas.description: Value internal to Terraform used to determine if a configuration set change requires a reboot.

schemas.name: resource_pool_id
schemas.description: The ID of a resource pool to put the virtual machine in.

schemas.name: run_tools_scripts_after_power_on
schemas.description: Enable the execution of post-power-on scripts when VMware tools is installed.

schemas.name: run_tools_scripts_after_resume
schemas.description: Enable the execution of post-resume scripts when VMware tools is installed.

schemas.name: run_tools_scripts_before_guest_reboot
schemas.description: Enable the execution of pre-reboot scripts when VMware tools is installed.

schemas.name: run_tools_scripts_before_guest_shutdown
schemas.description: Enable the execution of pre-shutdown scripts when VMware tools is installed.

schemas.name: run_tools_scripts_before_guest_standby
schemas.description: Enable the execution of pre-standby scripts when VMware tools is installed.

schemas.name: scsi_bus_sharing
schemas.description: Mode for sharing the SCSI bus. The modes are physicalSharing, virtualSharing, and noSharing.

schemas.name: scsi_controller_count
schemas.description: The number of SCSI controllers that Terraform manages on this virtual machine. This directly affects the amount of disks you can add to the virtual machine and the maximum disk unit number. Note that lowering this value does not remove controllers.

schemas.name: scsi_type
schemas.description: The type of SCSI bus this virtual machine will have. Can be one of lsilogic, lsilogic-sas or pvscsi.

schemas.name: shutdown_wait_timeout
schemas.description: The amount of time, in minutes, to wait for shutdown when making necessary updates to the virtual machine.

schemas.name: swap_placement_policy
schemas.description: The swap file placement policy for this virtual machine. Can be one of inherit, hostLocal, or vmDirectory.

schemas.name: sync_time_with_host
schemas.description: Enable guest clock synchronization with the host. Requires VMware tools to be installed.

schemas.name: tags
schemas.description: A list of tag IDs to apply to this object.

schemas.name: uuid
schemas.description: The UUID of the virtual machine. Also exposed as the ID of the resource.

schemas.name: vapp
schemas.description: vApp configuration data for this virtual machine. Can be used to provide configuration data for OVF images.

schemas.name: properties
schemas.description: A map of customizable vApp properties and their values. Allows customization of VMs cloned from OVF templates which have customizable vApp properties.

schemas.name: vapp_transport
schemas.description: vApp transport methods supported by virtual machine.

schemas.name: vmware_tools_status
schemas.description: The state of VMware tools in the guest. This will determine the proper course of action for some device operations.

schemas.name: vmx_path
schemas.description: The path of the virtual machine's configuration file in the VM's datastore.

schemas.name: wait_for_guest_net_routable
schemas.description: Controls whether or not the guest network waiter waits for a routable address. When false, the waiter does not wait for a default gateway, nor are IP addresses checked against any discovered default gateways as part of its success criteria.

schemas.name: wait_for_guest_net_timeout
schemas.description: The amount of time, in minutes, to wait for an available IP address on this virtual machine. A value less than 1 disables the waiter.

schemas.name: accessible
schemas.description: The connectivity status of the datastore. If this is false, some other computed attributes may be out of date.

schemas.name: capacity
schemas.description: Maximum capacity of the datastore, in MB.

schemas.name: custom_attributes
schemas.description: A list of custom attributes to set on this resource.

schemas.name: datastore_cluster_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datastore cluster to place the datastore in.

schemas.name: disks
schemas.description: The disks to add to the datastore.

schemas.name: folder
schemas.description: The path to the datastore folder to put the datastore in.

schemas.name: free_space
schemas.description: Available space of this datastore, in MB.

schemas.name: host_system_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the host to set up the datastore on.

schemas.name: maintenance_mode
schemas.description: The current maintenance mode state of the datastore.

schemas.name: multiple_host_access
schemas.description: If true, more than one host in the datacenter has been configured with access to the datastore.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name of the datastore.

schemas.name: tags
schemas.description: A list of tag IDs to apply to this object.

schemas.name: uncommitted_space
schemas.description: Total additional storage space, in MB, potentially used by all virtual machines on this datastore.

schemas.name: url
schemas.description: The unique locator for the datastore.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter the cluster is located in. Not required if using an absolute path.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name or absolute path to the cluster.

schemas.name: resource_pool_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the cluster's root resource pool.

schemas.name: managed_object_type
schemas.description: Object type for which the custom attribute is valid. If not specified, the attribute is valid for all managed object types.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The display name of the custom attribute.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name of the datacenter. This can be a name or path.	Can be omitted if there is only one datacenter in your inventory.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter the datastore is in. This is not required when using ESXi directly, or if there is only one datacenter in your infrastructure.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name or path of the datastore.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter the cluster is located in. Not required if using an absolute path.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name or absolute path to the datastore cluster.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter the DVS is in. This is required if the supplied path is not an absolute path containing a datacenter and there are multiple datacenters in your infrastructure.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name of the distributed virtual switch. This can be a name or path.

schemas.name: uplinks
schemas.description: The uplink ports on this DVS.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter to look for the host in.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name of the host. This can be a name or path.	If not provided, the default host is used.

schemas.name: resource_pool_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the host's root resource pool.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter the network is in. This is required if the supplied path is not an absolute path containing a datacenter and there are multiple datacenters in your infrastructure.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name or path of the network.

schemas.name: type
schemas.description: The managed object type of the network.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter the resource pool is in. This is not required when using ESXi directly, or if there is only one datacenter in your infrastructure.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name or path of the resource pool.

schemas.name: category_id
schemas.description: The unique identifier of the parent category for this tag.

schemas.name: description
schemas.description: The description of the tag.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The display name of the tag.

schemas.name: associable_types
schemas.description: Object types to which this category's tags can be attached.

schemas.name: cardinality
schemas.description: The associated cardinality of the category. Can be one of SINGLE (object can only be assigned one tag in this category) or MULTIPLE (object can be assigned multiple tags in this category).

schemas.name: description
schemas.description: The description of the category.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The display name of the category.

schemas.name: alternate_guest_name
schemas.description: The alternate guest name of the virtual machine when guest_id is a non-specific operating system, like otherGuest.

schemas.name: datacenter_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the datacenter the virtual machine is in. This is not required when using ESXi directly, or if there is only one datacenter in your infrastructure.

schemas.name: disks
schemas.description: Select configuration attributes from the disks on this virtual machine, sorted by bus and unit number.

schemas.name: firmware
schemas.description: The firmware type for this virtual machine.

schemas.name: guest_id
schemas.description: The guest ID of the virtual machine.

schemas.name: name
schemas.description: The name or path of the virtual machine.

schemas.name: network_interface_types
schemas.description: The types of network interfaces found on the virtual machine, sorted by unit number.

schemas.name: scsi_bus_sharing
schemas.description: Mode for sharing the SCSI bus.

schemas.name: scsi_controller_scan_count
schemas.description: The number of SCSI controllers to scan for disk sizes and controller types on.

schemas.name: scsi_type
schemas.description: The common SCSI bus type of all controllers on the virtual machine.

schemas.name: disks
schemas.description: The names of the disks discovered by the search.

schemas.name: filter
schemas.description: A regular expression to filter the disks against. Only disks with canonical names that match will be included.

schemas.name: host_system_id
schemas.description: The managed object ID of the host to search for disks on.

schemas.name: rescan
schemas.description: Rescan the system for disks before querying. This may lengthen the time it takes to gather information.
